user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_parse_arguments_:
```c
enum MHD_Result
MHD_parse_arguments_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      char *args,
                      MHD_ArgumentIterator_ cb,
                      void *cls)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  char *equals;
  char *amper;

  while ( (NULL != args) &&
          ('\0' != args[0]) )
  {
    size_t key_len;
    size_t value_len;
    equals = strchr (args, '=');
    amper = strchr (args, '&');
    if (NULL == amper)
    {
      /* last argument */
      if (NULL == equals)
      {
        /* last argument, without '=' */
        MHD_unescape_plus (args);
        key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             args);
        if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                          args,
                          key_len,
                          NULL,
                          0,
                          kind))
          return MHD_NO;
        break;
      }
      /* got 'foo=bar' */
      equals[0] = '\0';
      equals++;
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
      value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                             connection,
                                             equals);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        equals,
                        value_len,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      break;
    }
    /* amper is non-NULL here */
    amper[0] = '\0';
    amper++;
    if ( (NULL == equals) ||
         (equals >= amper) )
    {
      /* got 'foo&bar' or 'foo&bar=val', add key 'foo' with NULL for value */
      MHD_unescape_plus (args);
      key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           args);
      if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        NULL,
                        0,
                        kind))
        return MHD_NO;
      /* continue with 'bar' */
      args = amper;
      continue;
    }
    /* equals and amper are non-NULL here, and equals < amper,
 so we got regular 'foo=value&bar...'-kind of argument */
    equals[0] = '\0';
    equals++;
    MHD_unescape_plus (args);
    key_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                         connection,
                                         args);
    MHD_unescape_plus (equals);
    value_len = daemon->unescape_callback (daemon->unescape_callback_cls,
                                           connection,
                                           equals);
    if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                      args,
                      key_len,
                      equals,
                      value_len,
                      kind))
      return MHD_NO;
    args = amper;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                          args,
                          key_len,
                          NULL,
                          0,
                          kind))

if (MHD_NO == cb (cls,
                        args,
                        key_len,
                        equals,
                        value_len,
                        kind))

enum MHD_Result
MHD_parse_arguments_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      char *args,
                      MHD_ArgumentIterator_ cb,
                      void *cls)
explanation:
The listed fragments declare or pass pointer-typed parameters/locals that could potentially be const-qualified (function parameter list, local daemon pointer, cb and cls parameters, and uses of connection/args in callbacks). These should be investigated to determine whether the pointed-to objects are modified (in which case const is not appropriate) or could be qualified const to satisfy MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.

Other code fragments were not listed because they either: (a) clearly modify the pointed-to characters (e.g. equals[0] = '\0'; amper[0] = '\0'; increments equals++; amper++; calls to MHD_unescape_plus which implies in-place modification), so those pointers cannot be const-qualified; (b) are non-pointer scalar operations (size_t key_len/value_len, enum handling, control flow) and thus not relevant to pointer const qualification; or (c) are uses of pointers where the relevant declaration is already included above (for example multiple occurrences of the same cb or unescape_callback calls use the same pointer parameters already listed). If further investigation shows any of the listed fragments actually require mutable pointers (because called functions modify the data), they can be ruled out from Rule 8.13 concerns.
